pull.title: Save/restore column sizes of the tables in the Peers tab

repo.name: gui
repo.description: Bitcoin Core GUI staging repository. Please do not fork unless for development reasons.

events.body:
ACK dda2f65d754aa05d8191e79e4db2189e79988443, tested on macOS 11.2.3 Qt 5.15.2

This PR successfully saves/restores the column sizes in the peers tab. Below are some screenshots showing the behavior:

**Start**
![Screen Shot 2021-03-25 at 10 42 18 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23396902/112570142-e1b3f480-8dbb-11eb-8465-27e3d17533f1.png)

**Resize**
![Screen Shot 2021-03-25 at 10 42 42 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23396902/112570166-eb3d5c80-8dbb-11eb-8a82-2dd094b39dbe.png)

**Close and Restart**
![Screen Shot 2021-03-25 at 10 43 05 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23396902/112570197-f8f2e200-8dbb-11eb-95a5-17c91854a0bc.png)

Very practical improvement.

ACK dda2f65d754aa05d8191e79e4db2189e79988443 code review, debug build is clean, tested repeatedly with both "Peers" and "Banned Peers" column widths and different shutdown methods. Tested with Qt 5.15.2 on Debian 5.10.19-1 (2021-03-02).

Changes are straightforward. I'm not a Qt expert so I briefly checked the Qt 5.15 `QByteArray`, `saveState` and `restoreState` docs and version compats.

@jonatack @jarolrod 

Do you mind re-reviewing this PR?

Rebased 002d0e0d998d4c15d86990f9ce41d981e0bad7fc -> 03370446f7fc4936596c7b0d689ab425bdbc825d ([pr256.02](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr256.02) -> [pr256.03](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr256.03)) due to the conflict with #194.

ACK 03370446f7fc4936596c7b0d689ab425bdbc825d

patch looks good

| Start           | Resize         | Restart         |
| ----------- | ----------- | ------------ |
| ![Screen Shot 2021-05-12 at 10 41 14 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23396902/118070302-a2ddfc00-b373-11eb-8b22-0108c592129d.png) | ![Screen Shot 2021-05-12 at 10 41 40 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23396902/118070309-a70a1980-b373-11eb-86e3-fc3b9abf9713.png) | ![Screen Shot 2021-05-12 at 10 43 35 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23396902/118070339-b4270880-b373-11eb-9b5a-83860bed5ab5.png) |

@jonatack @promag 

Hoping on confirming your ACKs after the recent rebasing :)

events.body: Rebased 03370446f7fc4936596c7b0d689ab425bdbc825d -> fb1b1e0f3eae32b087347889ed7502b7f2c48549 ([pr256.03](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr256.03) -> [pr256.04](https://github.com/hebasto/gui/commits/pr256.04)) due to the conflict with #123.

This is a real UX improvement, thanks!

ACK fb1b1e0f3eae32b087347889ed7502b7f2c48549 code review, debug-built and tested

I am seeing some unusual flickering in the `User Agent` header, but this is also the case in current master 38ab7d0765e52b8. I don't recall seeing it before but am not sure.

ACK fb1b1e0f3eae32b087347889ed7502b7f2c48549

comments.body: An alternative could be to use `QHeaderView::sectionResized` signal.
Load `m_peer_widget_header_state` in constructor where `settings` already exists.

@promag 

Thanks for raising this question!

From my [experience](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/gui/pull/205#issuecomment-807812020) `QTableView::setColumnWidth` does not work without model set (but it is not documented by Qt).

Did I miss something? Does it work for you?
I mean move L620 to constructor but leave `restoreState()` here.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1186,6 +1198,11 @@ void RPCConsole::showEvent(QShowEvent *event)
 
 void RPCConsole::hideEvent(QHideEvent *event)
 {
+    // It is too late to call QHeaderView::saveState() in ~RPCConsole(), as all of
comments.body:
Yes, using `QHeaderView::sectionResized` signal is a clearer solution. But most of them are redundant, as we are interested in the final state only.

Do you think we should prefer clear code (I admit that using a comment to explain code is a bad sign)?
If so, I'll be happy to implement your suggestion.

comments.body:
On the other hand with current approach it always save even if you dont resize.

Is the signal emitted while resizing? Not only at the end? (Didnt test)
